Which family does the rubella virus belong to?
questions.solution:
• The rubella virus belongs to the family Togaviridae.
  • Togaviridae is a family of RNA viruses that are characterized by their enveloped structure and positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome.
  • This family includes several important human pathogens, and rubella virus is one of them.

questions.solution: Azoles inhibit the synthesis of ergosterol, a component of fungal cell membranes, by inhibiting the activity of the enzyme lanosterol 14-alpha-demethylase. This results in membrane instability and cell death.

A 3-year-old child has a single lytic lesion in the skull that is not causing any organ damage. Examination of the blood and urine is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The presence of a single lytic lesion in the skull with no organ damage in a 3-year-old child points towards Localised Langerhans cell histiocytosis (option 3).
MM(Multiple myeloma) (option 2) can have lytic lesions in the skull but typically has end-organ damage (CRAB) and occurs in the elderly. 
AML and ALL(option 1 and option 4) both can have bony pain due to marrow proliferation but do not usually cause an isolated lytic lesion in the skull.

Which metabolic imbalance is the most significant in necrotizing enterocolitis?
questions.solution:
• Necrotizing enterocolitis is a severe condition affecting premature neonates, characterized by inflammation and necrosis of the intestine. It is associated with various metabolic disturbances due to the compromised blood flow to the intestines and the release of inflammatory mediators.
  • Metabolic acidosis is the most significant metabolic abnormality seen in NEC. Dysbiosis contributing to NEC and abnormal gut bacterial flora produces a lot of propionic acids (SCFA) and necrosis leading to lactic acidosis - both finally contributing to a decrease in blood pH and the development of metabolic acidosis.

Which of the following triangles is depicted in the below image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Calot's triangle 
 
  • The triangle in the image is Calot's triangle.
  • It is an anatomical triangle in the liver that is associated with the surgical anatomy of the liver.
  • The triangle is bounded by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior surface of the liver.

  



Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice 42 nd Edition Page No 1464e.147

Which of the following conditions exhibits an Osborn J wave?
questions.solution:
• An Osborn J wave, also known as an Osborn wave or J wave, is a deflection in the ECG (electrocardiogram) seen in hypothermia.
  • It appears as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the QRS complex and the ST segment). The J wave is most commonly observed in leads with prominent R waves, such as the precordial leads (V2 to V6) or the high lateral leads (I and aVL).
